review.title: Estimating the unseen from multiple populations
review.abstract: Given samples from a distribution, how many new elements should we expect to find if we continue sampling this distribution? This is an important and actively studied problem, with many applications ranging from unseen species estimation to genomics. We generalize this extrapolation and related unseen estimation problems to the multiple population setting, where population $j$ has an unknown distribution $D_j$ from which we observe $n_j$ samples. We derive an optimal estimator for the total number of elements we expect to find among new samples across the populations. Surprisingly, we prove that our estimator's accuracy is independent of the number of populations. We also develop an efficient optimization algorithm to solve the more general problem of estimating multi-population frequency distributions. We validate our methods and theory through extensive experiments. Finally, on a real dataset of human genomes across multiple ancestries, we demonstrate how our approach for unseen estimation can enable cohort designs that can discover interesting mutations with greater efficiency.
histories: 13 pages, 3 figures, appearing at the International Conference on Machine Learning 2017 (ICML 2017)
review.COMMENTS: 13 pages, 3 figures, appearing at the International Conference on Machine Learning 2017 (ICML 2017)

sections.heading: 2. Related works
sections.text: The problem of estimating the properties of the unobserved part of a distribution, since n samples, and the related problem of estimating the number of new domain elements that are likely to be observed when additional cn samples are collected, comes from the work of I.J. Good and A. Turing (Good, 1953), and R.A. Fisher (Fisher et al., 1943), which was quickly followed by (Gut & Toulmin, 1956), which introduced the Good Toulmin Estimator. While the Good Toulmin Estimator is always unbiased, the variance increases rapidly for c ≥ 1. Subsequent work, including (Efron & Thisted, 1976), have proposed "smoothing" approaches that compensate the bias and variance for this type of approach.

We model the multi-population invisible estimate as a two-step process. In the first period, we will collect additional samples from the total population, which we cannot evaluate. sections.heading: 5. Estimating the multi-population frequency distribution
sections.text: While we need to estimate the number of invisible elements in a new sample, it is difficult to find good estimators of other statistics (e.g. number of new elements we have observed) directly from the fingerprints. As discussed in Sec. 3, we can also estimate the less direct approach to the actual underlying multi-population history. In view of an accurate reconstruction of this underlying histogram, we can then estimate any symmetrical statistics of the future samples. We discuss some of the uses of such representation in Section 5.Recovering the frequency distribution The multi-population histograms for restoring the multi-population histograms is a natural extension of the population number presented in Valiant & Valiant (2011; 2013).Estimulation of multi-population histograms: Core Approach.

sections.heading: 7. Discussion
sections.text: We provide a weighted linear estimator for the number of new elements and a general optimization algorithm for estimating the multipopulation histogram. These two approaches have a complementary strength. The weighted linear estimator U-W specifically estimates the number of invisible elements. Its accuracy is independent of the number of populations m, and it is optimal at worst. This can be a good method, especially if m is large and the extrapolation factor is small compared to recording the number of samples observed. However, if the extrapolation is greater, U-W is consistently downward due to its variance-reducing weights. For relatively small populations (m = 2, 3, 4) and larger extrapolation factors, the invisible predictions of our histogram estimators H-count and H-ll are much more precise than U-W. While both probably show comparable performance in the worst case, the linear estimation factors are always larger than the worst case, we consider the worst extrapolative factors.

sections.heading: B. Multi-population Earth Mover’s Distance
sections.text: We define a natural distance metric for multi-population histograms, which is a measure of the extent to which the corresponding distributions are similar, up to a relabeling of the elements: Definition B.1. sections.heading: C. Additional experiments
sections.text: We tested the predictive accuracy of H-counting using another statistic: the number of elements that we expect to find at least twice in the new samples, see Fig. 3.

metadata.abstractText: Given samples from a distribution, how many new elements should we expect to find if we continue sampling this distribution? This is an important and actively studied problem, with many applications ranging from unseen species estimation to genomics. We generalize this extrapolation and related unseen estimation problems to the multiple population setting, where population j has an unknown distributionDj from which we observe nj samples. We derive an optimal estimator for the total number of elements we expect to find among new samples across the populations. Surprisingly, we prove that our estimator’s accuracy is independent of the number of populations. We also develop an efficient optimization algorithm to solve the more general problem of estimating multi-population frequency distributions. We validate our methods and theory through extensive experiments. Finally, on a real dataset of human genomes across multiple ancestries, we demonstrate how our approach for unseen estimation can enable cohort designs that can discover interesting mutations with greater efficiency.
